title: SB 1325
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The department reviews and approves plans submitted under Section 25246 of the Health and Safety Code if they comply with regulations and state/federal laws. Approval is contingent on compliance with Water Code Section 13227. The department will not approve the plan until it meets certain conditions: approval under Water Code Section 13227, 60 days after submission for interim status facilities, or immediate approval for public health, safety, or environmental protection. Any department action is subject to Section 25204.5. The director may approve the plan immediately if it is necessary to protect public health, safety, or the environment. Department actions are subject to Section 25204.5, and hazardous waste facility postclosure requirements can be imposed on owners or operators through enforcement orders, agreements, or permits. The hazardous waste facility postclosure plan must be approved in compliance with the California Environmental Quality Act. The department must allow public involvement before approving or modifying the plan. The department determines if a modification is significant based on class 3 permit criteria and public concern. The California Code of Regulations, Division 4.5, Title 22, Chapter 20 outlines criteria for determining if a proposed modification constitutes a class 3 modification. The department considers public concern and the complexity of the proposed change in making this determination. The department has the authority to order necessary actions at a facility to protect public health or safety. If the department imposes a hazardous waste facility postclosure plan through an enforcement order or agreement, the owner must pay specified fees or enter a cost reimbursement agreement. The commencement of the postclosure period triggers the payment of required fees. Upon commencement of the postclosure period, the owner must pay the fee required by Section 25205.7. The effective date of the postclosure permit, enforcement order, or enforceable agreement marks the start of the postclosure period. The department may enforce a postclosure plan through actions such as filing an injunction, requiring corrective action, and assessing civil penalties for violations. The department can enforce a postclosure plan by taking actions like filing for civil penalties for violations. Postclosure plan requirements must be adopted by the department by January 1, 2018. The department must adopt regulations by January 1, 2018, to impose postclosure plan requirements. If deemed necessary, the department can replace an enforcement order with a postclosure permit for a hazardous waste facility. The department has the authority to order actions to protect public health and the environment at a facility. Section 25247 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to require the department to review and approve plans that comply with regulations before approval. The department must approve a plan for a facility under certain conditions, including approval under Water Code Section 13227, submission for 60 days without denial, or immediate approval for public health or safety. Any department action is subject to Section 25204.5. The director may approve a plan for a facility if it is necessary to protect public health, safety, or the environment. Department actions are subject to Section 25204.5, and hazardous waste facility postclosure requirements can be imposed through enforcement orders, agreements, or permits. The hazardous waste facility postclosure plan must be approved in compliance with the California Environmental Quality Act. The department must allow public involvement before approving or modifying the plan. A "significant modification" for a hazardous waste facility is determined based on whether it would constitute a class 3 permit modification. The department considers similarities to class 3 modifications in regulations and public concerns when making this determination. In determining if a proposed modification for a hazardous waste facility constitutes a class 3 modification, the department also considers public concern and the complexity of the proposed change. The department has the authority to order necessary actions at a facility to protect public health or safety. If the department issues a hazardous waste facility postclosure plan through an enforcement order or agreement, the owner must enter a cost reimbursement agreement and pay the required fee at the start of the postclosure period. The postclosure period begins with the effective date of the permit, order, or agreement. The department may enforce a postclosure plan through various actions, including filing an injunction, requiring corrective action, and assessing civil penalties for violations. The department can enforce a postclosure plan by taking actions such as filing for civil penalties for violations. Subdivision (d) does not apply to postclosure plans with permits issued before December 31, 2003, unless mutually replaced with an enforcement order or agreement. Regulations for postclosure plan requirements must be adopted by the department by January 1, 2018. The department must adopt regulations by January 1, 2018, to impose postclosure plan requirements. If deemed necessary, the department can replace an enforcement order with a postclosure permit for a hazardous waste facility. The department has the authority to order necessary actions at a facility to protect public health, safety, or the environment. Section 1.5 of the bill includes amendments to Section 25247 of the Health and Safety Code, contingent on the enactment of Assembly Bill 1611 or Senate Bill 839 by January 1, 2017. If this bill is enacted last, the amended Section 25247 will only be in effect until the operative date of this bill. The bill includes amendments to Section 25247 of the Health and Safety Code. If enacted last, the amendments will only be in effect until the operative date of the bill.
